projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: BY THE Lord Lieutenant AND Council of Ireland.
div.p:
WHEREAS his Maje≈øtie by his Gracious Letters, bearing Date the two and twentieth day of September la≈øt to us the Lord Lieutenant directed, taking notice, that the late Commi≈ø≈øioners for executing the Acts of ≈øettlement & explanation, did not by virtue of their Commi≈ø≈øion proceed to the adjudication of any the Claims of the tran≈øplanted per≈øons in the Province of Connaught, or county of Clare, or to the ≈øettlement of anytheir e≈øtates or intere≈øts, except only the intere≈øts of ≈øuch Prote≈øtants, who before the fir≈øt day of September 1663, purcha≈øed Lands in Connaught or Clare from the ≈øaid tran≈øplanted per≈øons, ≈øo that the e≈øtates of the ≈øaid tran≈øplanted per≈øons which continued in their own hands, and were not within that time purcha≈øed by Prote≈øtants, remain ≈øubject to much doubt & uncertainty, whereby the Improvements of the ≈øaid lands are very much hindred, and ≈øuch of the ≈øaid tran≈øplanted per≈øons, as have been di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the lands ≈øet out unto them, have not yet been reprized for the ≈øame, according to his Maje≈øties Declaration of the thirtieth of November in the year (1660) for the ≈øettlement of this Kingdom of Ireland, which hath been ≈øince Confirmed by Act of Parliament in this Kingdome; For Remedy whereof his Maje≈øtie hath been Graciou≈øly plea≈øed by his ≈øaid Letters, to authorize us the Lord Lieutenant of this Kingdom, to Cau≈øe a Commi≈ø≈øion to be i≈ø≈øued under the great Seal of this Kingdome, directed to ≈øuch Commi≈ø≈øioners, as we the Lord Lieutenant with the advice of the privie Council in this Kingdom, ≈øhould think fit to nominiate and appoint, authorizing them or any three of them, to be his Maje≈øties Commi≈ø≈øioners, to hear and determine the claimes of all tran≈øplanted per≈øons in the ≈øaid Province of Connaught and County of Clare, touching the decrees they had, or the Lands ≈øet out to them in Lieu of their former E≈øtates, Except onely ≈øuch Lands as have been already di≈øpo≈øed of, by his Maje≈øties late Commi≈ø≈øioners for Executing the Acts of ≈øettlement and Explanation, and to ≈øtate the Quit-rents due to his Maje≈øtie out of the ≈øaid Lands, and to Exammine what Irregularities have been in the ≈øetting out and di≈øpo≈øal of the ≈øaid Lands, and to confirm the ju≈øt part thereof, and to enquire of all Lands forfeited to His Maje≈øtie by the ≈øaid Acts in the ≈øaid Province and County, and to di≈øpo≈øe of all or any ≈øuch forfeited Lands, as are or ≈øhall be found to be in His Maje≈øties di≈øpo≈øall, towards the ≈øati≈øfaction and Reprizall of ≈øuch tran≈øplanted Intere≈øts, as remaine yet un≈øati≈øfied or deficient, and to grant Certificates thereof, in order to the pa≈ø≈øing Letters Patents
therupon, in ≈øuch manner, as certificats were granted by the late Commi≈ø≈øioners for Executing the ≈øaid Acts of ≈øettlement & Explanation, to any per≈øons who≈øe Claims were adjudged before them, and to ob≈øerue ≈øuch In≈øtractions, as we the Lord Lieutenant and Council, ≈øhall think fit to give unto them, from time to time, for the better Execution of the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øion, & His Maje≈øtie by his ≈øaid Letters hath al≈øo authorized us the Lord Lieutenant, without any further warrant, to pa≈øs letters Patents under the great Seal of this Kingdom, upon the ≈øaid certificates, to the per≈øons therein Concerned, according to ≈øuch E≈øtates, as ≈øhall be thereby adjudged to belong to them, in ≈øuch manner and as fully to all intents and purpo≈øes, as Letters Patents have been u≈øually pa≈ø≈øed upon Certificates of his Maje≈øties late Commi≈ø≈øioners for executing the ≈øaid Acts of Setlement & explanation, and his Maje≈øties hath al≈øo thereby further declared, that the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners, and all Officers and Mini≈øters to be Employed by them, ≈øhall and may receive ≈øuch fees and allowances to be payd by the Parties who≈øe Claims ≈øhall be heard before them, as we the Lord Lieutenant and Councill ≈øhall think fit to appoint, ≈øo as the ≈øame do not exceed one Moyety of the ≈øeveral fees allowed to his Maje≈øties late Commi≈ø≈øioners, for putting in Execution the ≈øaid Acts of ≈øettlement, and Explanation, and their Officers and Mini≈øters. And we the Lord Lieutenant and Council in pur≈øuance of his Maje≈øties ≈øaid Letters, having Nominated and appointed Sir Robert Booth Knight, Lord Chief Iu≈øtice of his Maje≈øties Court of Common Pleas, Sir Charles Meredith Knight, Chancellor of his Maje≈øties Court of Exchequer, Thomas Ratcliff E≈øq Henry Henn E≈øq one of the Barons of his Maje≈øties Court of Exchequer, and Sir Richard Reynell Knight, one of the Iu≈øtices of his Maje≈øties Court of Chiefplace, to be his Maje≈øties Commi≈ø≈øioners, for hearing and determining the Claims of all Tran≈øplanted per≈øons in the ≈øaid Province of Connaught and County of Clare, and to execute all other the matters contained in his Maje≈øties ≈øaid Letters, and a Commi≈ø≈øion being ≈øince pa≈øt unto them under the great Seal of this Kingdome to that purpo≈øe. We have thought fit to give this publique notice thereof to all per≈øons concerned in any of the ≈øaid Tran≈øplanted Lands, and that the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners will begin to ≈øit pupliquely upon the Execution of the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øion, on the one and twentieth day of Augu≈øt next, at the place where the late Court of Claimes ≈øate in the Kings Inns, Dublin. And we do hereby require all per≈øons concerned in any of the ≈øaid Lands, that by them≈øelves or their Agents, they do put in their Claims before the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners at the Office of their Regi≈øter in the Kings-Inns, Dublin, before the ≈øaid one and twentieth day of Augu≈øt next. And that they do with all convenient ≈øpeed apply them≈øelves to the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners for the hearing and determining of their ≈øaid Claims, and pro≈øecute the ≈øame with effect in ≈øuch manner and at ≈øuch time, as by his Maje≈øties ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners ≈øhall be directed, whereof publique notice will be given by the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners, a≈ø≈øoon as they ≈øhall have agreed upon the order and method of their proceedings.
div.closer:
Given at the Council Chamber in Dublin the 26th day of Iune, one thou≈øand ≈øix hundred ≈øeventy ≈øix.
Ja: Armachanus.
Art: Granard.
Hen: Miden≈øis.
R: Coote.
Heugh: Glenaully.
Rob: Fitz-Gerald.
J: Povey.
Jo: By≈ø≈øe.

Wm: Gore.
Ol: St. George.
Hans: Hamilton.
Wm: Flower.
Ran: Clayton.
GOD SAVE THE KING

div.p: Dublin, Printed by Benjamin Tooke, Printer to the Kings Mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øtie; and are to be ≈øold by Jo≈øeph Wilde Booke≈øeller in Ca≈øtle≈øtreet. 1676.
